intro: Silene greenei subsp. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrowleaf eveningprimrose, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer, typically in clusters at the ends of the stems. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Silene greenei subsp. angustifolia is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with similar morphological traits.
